message: Looks like Dorothy still hasn't come back.
With management this sloppy, it's a wonder nothing's gone wrong yet.
There's no one here.
Where on earth did Dorothy at the front desk go?

name: Gardner
message: Even if it's an archives with hardly any visitors, leaving your post carelessly during work hours is just plain negligence！
Gardner looks seriously pissed off.
Maybe even a not-so-friendly staff member is better than no one at all.

name: Gardner
message: But, guess you could say this actually works out for us.
Now we can sneak into the president's office while nobody's around.
I left the reading room and went back to the reception desk in the hall.
Dorothy, the archives staff, glanced our way, not looking all that interested.

name: Dorothy
message: Did you find the record you were after？
This is the reception desk at the archives.
Dorothy looks puzzled as she sees us.
Besides us, there's no one else in this not-so-big hall.
Our footsteps echoed across the marble floor, like tracing the marks of glory, and bounced all around the hall.

At the reception of the Archives, a bespectacled woman, dressed like a clerk and looking just about twenty, is waiting. She fits perfectly at the eerily deserted reception of the Archives, as if she was made for it.

On the chest of the woman in the dark blue clothes, there's a nameplate showing her position. Next to the name 'Dorothy Sayers,' there's a photo of her with a composed expression, making it obvious at a glance that she's an Archives staff member.

name: Dorothy
message: Are you looking for something? Is there anything I can help you with?
Contrary to her unfriendly appearance, the woman seems willing enough to perform her duties as staff. Still, her tone is extremely businesslike and her words carry no inflection.
It's a pretty impressive building for a rundown rural Archives.
The only shame is, the villagers and officials don't seem all that enthusiastic about preserving this building.
This is the reception desk of the Archives.
The floor is made of marble, but it's quite old and apparently not well maintained—it looks like it's lost its distinctive shine long ago.
The door in the back probably used to connect to the university grounds.
I don't know how much stuff they've collected, but it's pretty unlikely the content beats the appearance.
Neatly organized index cards line the entire wall. If a woman named Dorothy manages all this by herself, she must be seriously meticulous.
Looks like these index cards were set up to handle inquiries about the collection of books and all kinds of other items.
But with zero tourists visiting the village, and the villagers themselves not caring about their own history, I doubt these cards are actually getting much use.
The top of the counter is tidy, with nothing personal that gives off Dorothy's vibe at all.
In an archive that barely gets any visitors, I wonder how she kills all that boring time.
The counter that's been used for ages has had its shine completely dulled, turned black and basically just become worthless junk.
Back when this building used to be a university, this was probably just a regular hall where students gathered, so it shouldn't be all that old.
It must have been treated pretty roughly for a long time.

name: Dorothy
message: Even if you look at me with such clingy eyes, it won't work, I'm just doing exactly what I'm supposed to do.

name: Dorothy
message: Please state your business！
If you don't have any business, please go home.
She really looks like a clerk, like a model from the new employee training manual they'd use at a government office.
The deep navy, almost uniform-like outfit weirdly suits her, and it's hard to imagine what she'd look like in any other clothes.

name: Dorothy
message: Is something wrong? If you don't tell me what you're looking into, there's really nothing I can do...
Dorothy's words are irritated and sharp.
There's also a blatantly overbearing vibe, typical of government officials.

name: Dorothy
message: なんとか言ったらどう？
It's my job too, so don't make extra trouble for me！

name: Dorothy
message: I can’t let you into the principal’s office！

name: Jonathan
message: Can you tell me more about that incident？
What kind of guy was this Dunwich?

name: Dorothy
message: Well... this is all before I was born.
But, it seems like Mr. Dunwich was one of the wealthiest people in the village.

name: Gardner
message: マーシュ老人の言っていた事と合致する。
So in other words, that 'Dunwich family' was basically the symbol of Innsmouth.

name: Dorothy
message: That's not all there is to it.
Mr. Dunwich was apparently the president of Miskatonic University, which was the predecessor to this Archives.

name: Dorothy
message: The university was shut down right after the incident...　　　　　　So, I'm the last president of Miskatonic University.

name: Cordelia
message: Fate sure is ironic, huh.
Then　it　totally　sounds　like　the　university　got　shut　down　because　of　that　Dunwich　guy　or　something.

name: Gardner
message: If one of the village's top men of ability, and also a man of great learning, suddenly goes mad‥‥‥‥‥

name: Jonathan
message: Um, I want to know more about Dunwich in detail.
Aren't there any materials left about it？

name: Dorothy
message: Let me think...
I'm pretty sure it's here, but it's not exactly organized.　　　　　　　Looks like you'll have to search for it yourself.

name: Jonathan
message: So then, where』s the casebook that has the 'Dunwich Incident' written in it？

name: Dorothy
message: Go into the reading room and it's on the bookshelf immediately to your left.
Since it's an official record, it might be plain and hard to recognize.

name: Jonathan
message: I'll go look for it.

name: Dorothy
message: Anything else？

name: Jonathan
message: Let's see‥‥‥‥

name: Jonathan
message: Then, how about calling it the 'Innsmouth look'？
Is there any material that mentions that word?

name: Dorothy
message: あなた、そんな言葉どこで覚えてきたんです？
If you say stuff like that here in Arkham, you’re not gonna get away with it, you know？

name: Gardner
message: I've got plenty of experience with that already.

name: Dorothy
message: If it's Dorothy, she should understand.
このアーカムで、そんな資料があるわけないでしょう？

name: Dorothy
message: 他に何かご用は？

name: Gardner
message: 別にないようだな。
Let's try looking into the 'Dunwich Incident'.

name: Dorothy
message: Please do your best.
Dorothy says that in a flat tone, like she wants to get away from us as soon as possible.

name: Jonathan
message: The reading room, huh.

name: Jonathan
message: I don't know how many books are in this collection, but it looks like it's gonna be a pretty tough job.

name: Gardner
message: Yeah‥‥‥‥‥‥

name: Gardner
message: Wait, didn't you say that Dunwich used to be the president of Miskatonic University？

name: Dorothy
message: That's right.

name: Gardner
message: Didn't this Archives just use the university building as it was after the school shut down？

name: Dorothy
message: Yeah, that's right, but... wait a second！

name: Gardner
message: The president's office that Dunwich used is still left just as it was, right？

name: Dorothy
message: No way, nobody's set foot in that room since the school closed down.

name: Gardner
message: Isn't that even more convenient?
事件を起こす前に、ダニッジが何かを書き残している　　　　　　　　かもしれないじゃないか。

name: Dorothy
message: I can't let you into the president's office！

name: Jonathan
message: Instead of looking at things like case records, if there's something like a memoir left by the person themselves, that's going to be more of a clue to understanding the case.

name: Dorothy
message: Listen to me！
No　one’s　allowed　to　enter　the　president’s　office.

name: Jonathan
message: Do you have any criminal records from about 50 years ago？
Something　like　someone's　daily　log　would　be　fine,　but　a　case　law　book　would　be　even　better.
The woman, with an openly suspicious look that said, 'Why would you want to see something like that？', flipped through the index behind her.

name: Dorothy
message: What kind of case are you looking for？
Even if it's just a small village, they've got everything from petty crimes like theft to murder and poaching, like some kind of crime expo.

name: Gardner
message: Of course, I don’t give a shit about some petty thief.
What we're looking for is a murder case.

name: Dorothy
message: 殺人ねぇ‥‥‥‥‥‥
It shouldn't be that many, so I think it's probably all put together in one book.

name: Thomas
message: That old geezer was making a big fuss, huh.
Some　crazy　bastard　snapped　and　went　and　slaughtered　your　whole　family　or　something‥‥‥‥

name: Dorothy
message: ああ、『ダニッジ事件』の事ですね。
それなら５０年前どころじゃありませんわ。

name: Jonathan
message: When you say 'The Dunwich Incident'？
Was it really that famous of an incident?

name: Dorothy
message: Yeah, well......
It　must　have　been　a　uniquely　brutal　case.

name: Thomas
message: あんたが子供の頃の話って訳ではないだろう。
No way, miss, do you get mistaken for being younger？

name: Dorothy
message: I'm still only 23！
Library
President's Office
Go outside
